linkTarget.anchoringText: Using the finite-difference method of one of the most common computational simulators (Eclipse Schlumberger), a case of entering a low-permeable reservoir (Kper<1 mD) by a horizontal well, which penetrated two superconductive vertical intervals (Kper>>100 mD) spreading deep down the stratum to the distance significantly exceeding the borehole diameter (Wf<Rwell, Xf>>Rwell) was analyzed on a fine screen. Actually, the case of penetration of two subvertical conductive macrofractures is simulated (figure 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Model of HW in a Low-Permeable Reservoir. Colour graduation - pressure in bars. White lines - cell contacts

formatted-caption.caption-text: Model of HW in a Low-Permeable Reservoir. Colour graduation - pressure in bars. White lines - cell contacts

linkTarget.anchoringText: Several modeling sessions with varying half the length of the fractures and the effective length of the horizontal hole were carried out. Based on the results, even in the case of filtration at the maximum HW length for the experiment (750 m) and the minimum size of fractures (5 m), the share of the latter in the total well stream exceeds 50% all the same (Figure 2). Flowrate distribution along the hole length is shown in Figure 3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3.2
image-wrap.caption: Dependence Diagrams of the Fracture Share in the Total Well Flowrate with Various Correlation of Computational Model Parameters. A) Dependence of the share of inflow from fractures to the horizontal hole with the fixed length (500 m) at various half-lengths of fractures. B) Dependence of the share of fractures with the fixed half-length (10 m) in the total volume inflow at various lengths of the horizontal section of the borehole

formatted-caption.caption-text: Dependence Diagrams of the Fracture Share in the Total Well Flowrate with Various Correlation of Computational Model Parameters. A) Dependence of the share of inflow from fractures to the horizontal hole with the fixed length (500 m) at various half-lengths of fractures. B) Dependence of the share of fractures with the fixed half-length (10 m) in the total volume inflow at various lengths of the horizontal section of the borehole

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Dependence of the share of inflow from fractures to the horizontal hole with the fixed length (500 m) at various half-lengths of fractures
Dependence of the share of fractures with the fixed half-length (10 m) in the total volume inflow at various lengths of the horizontal section of the borehole

linkTarget.anchoringText: Several modeling sessions with varying half the length of the fractures and the effective length of the horizontal hole were carried out. Based on the results, even in the case of filtration at the maximum HW length for the experiment (750 m) and the minimum size of fractures (5 m), the share of the latter in the total well stream exceeds 50% all the same (Figure 2). Flowrate distribution along the hole length is shown in Figure 3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3.3
image-wrap.caption: Graph of Distribution of Specific Flowrate across the Horizontal Section of the Borehole for a Hole 500 Meter Long and Fractures with Half-Length of 50 Meters Peaks correspond to fracture position in the computational model

linkTarget.anchoringText: The main site of the above mentioned field (hereinafter referred to as NGKM-1) is a massive carbonate deposit (Figure 4) lithologically sealed and represented by a wide range of carbonate rocks, non-uniform as to lithology and reservoir porosity and permeability.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Geological Column NGKM-1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Geological Column NGKM-1

linkTarget.anchoringText: Additional specific features are availability of two types of fluid contacts (GOC, WOC), hydrogen sulphide content in the product, as well as abundance of faults throughout the occurrence area (Figure 5) and heavy compartmentalization of the reservoir. The latter fact played an important role in determination of the process solution for the field drilling using horizontal (subhorizontal) wells to ensure full involvement of all veins (Figure 6).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Reservoir Pressure Map Tile of Stratum P1art of NGKM-1. Red lines indicate the largest faults

formatted-caption.caption-text: Reservoir Pressure Map Tile of Stratum P1art of NGKM-1. Red lines indicate the largest faults

linkTarget.anchoringText: Additional specific features are availability of two types of fluid contacts (GOC, WOC), hydrogen sulphide content in the product, as well as abundance of faults throughout the occurrence area (Figure 5) and heavy compartmentalization of the reservoir. The latter fact played an important role in determination of the process solution for the field drilling using horizontal (subhorizontal) wells to ensure full involvement of all veins (Figure 6).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Illustration of a Typical Hole Path at NGKM-1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Illustration of a Typical Hole Path at NGKM-1

linkTarget.anchoringText: Well stock is also covered by a wide range of studies including such advanced survey methods as formation microimagers, apart from the standard well logging set and a large amount of core data (Figure 7). It shall be noted that the surveys using formation microimagers were only carried out in pilot horizontal boreholes with the view to determine the fracture propagation azimuth at a separate field site to adjust the direction of certain horizontal holes. It impeded well logging and FMI data correlation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Image Sweep Based on Logging Data for One of the Wells at NGKM-1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Image Sweep Based on Logging Data for One of the Wells at NGKM-1

linkTarget.anchoringText: However, despite thorough refinement of the survey programme, involving experts of the subsoil user, contactor and R&D center, the study results were not satisfactory (Figures 8-9).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Results of Combination of Initial Data (Dots) and Model Curves (Lines) for the Pressure Buildup Curve Cycle. The top of the graphs is a bottom-hole pressure change curve (atm.), the bottom – liquid rate curves

formatted-caption.caption-text: Results of Combination of Initial Data (Dots) and Model Curves (Lines) for the Pressure Buildup Curve Cycle. The top of the graphs is a bottom-hole pressure change curve (atm.), the bottom – liquid rate curves

linkTarget.anchoringText: However, despite thorough refinement of the survey programme, involving experts of the subsoil user, contactor and R&D center, the study results were not satisfactory (Figures 8-9).

linkTarget.anchoringText: As the result, the impact produced by the afterflow coefficient was significantly reduced, which fact enabled tracing of flow regime formation at the wells, starting from the first minute of shutdown (Figures 10-11).

linkTarget.anchoringText: As the result, the impact produced by the afterflow coefficient was significantly reduced, which fact enabled tracing of flow regime formation at the wells, starting from the first minute of shutdown (Figures 10-11).

image-wrap.caption: Correlation of Log-Log Graphs for the Double Porosity Model (Orange Curves) and the Actual Output for Well **58 at NGKM-1 (Green Curves)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The results of the survey programme implementation at more than 20 wells demonstrated, that the pressure derivative in horizontal boreholes (Figure 11) may be interpreted using three main hydrodynamically similar models (Figure 12).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Log-Log Derivative Behavior for Well **33-1G at NGKM-1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log-Log Derivative Behavior for Well **33-1G at NGKM-1

linkTarget.anchoringText: According to Fig. 13, the satisfactory combination of model and actual derivatives can be obtained using filtration models, absolutely different in terms of the well design.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Results of Combination of Actual and Model Data for Various Filtration Models

formatted-caption.caption-text: Results of Combination of Actual and Model Data for Various Filtration Models

linkTarget.anchoringText: This fact is due to phase segregation in the horizontal hole section at low flowrate (Figure 14).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3.14
image-wrap.caption: Phase Segregation in the Horizontal Hole Section at Various Flow Rates and Inclination Values according to Schlumberger

formatted-caption.caption-text: Phase Segregation in the Horizontal Hole Section at Various Flow Rates and Inclination Values according to Schlumberger

linkTarget.anchoringText: At the first stage of studies, wells located at considerable distance from one another were selected in the areas of interest at the field (Figure 15). Well selection was based on subsurface uncertainty and process capability of work performance.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: NGKM-1 Map Tile by the Coherence Attribute The paths of holes from the first well logging group are highlighted in red

formatted-caption.caption-text: NGKM-1 Map Tile by the Coherence Attribute The paths of holes from the first well logging group are highlighted in red

linkTarget.anchoringText: In all wells, where logging was carried out, the predicted performance of the main field geophysical control methods was observed. Primarily, there were registered characteristic changes in grainsize analysis methods and barometry methods in accordance with the borehole path, i.e. display of high- or low-density fluid accumulation (dielectric permeability, conductivity) in the upper and lower intervals of the path, respectively. Temperature logs demonstrated remarkable local negative anomalies, which confirmed previously stated hypotheses of impact produced by local inflows on the well performance (Figures 16-21).

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Example of a Composite Log for Completed Well Logging

formatted-caption.caption-text: Example of a Composite Log for Completed Well Logging

linkTarget.anchoringText: Survey carried out in one of the wells, using an imported hardware system (FSI Schlumberger), enabled confirmation of the informative value of domestic analogues regarding high-quality determination of inflow intervals in the current geotechnical conditions (Figure 22).

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: Correlation of composite logs obtained based on the data from imported (left) and domestic (right) hardware

formatted-caption.caption-text: Correlation of composite logs obtained based on the data from imported (left) and domestic (right) hardware

linkTarget.anchoringText: The undeniable advantage of an imported hardware system is availability of a flow meter distributed across the cross-section (Figure 23), which enables determination of the fluid flow rate in various parts of the borehole and assessment of stratification of such fluid in composition by using additional optical sensors. This enables more detailed identification of fluid ingress intervals, as well as quantitative assessment of inflow in some interval.

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: Schematic Layout of the Flowmeter Distributed across the Cross-Section in the Flow Skan Imager (Schlumberger)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic Layout of the Flowmeter Distributed across the Cross-Section in the Flow Skan Imager (Schlumberger)

linkTarget.anchoringText: This method in combination with highly precise temperature logging enables detailing inflow intervals with the best vertical resolution (to dozens of centimeters) and determination of the inflow nature. This method is based on noise sensing in an operating well, and the frequency-amplitude characteristic of noise could indicate the environment of fluid filtration. Applying various mathematical filters to the noise spectrum in the well, the flow intervals can be directly divided by the reservoir matrix (0.3-1 kHz) and by fractures (15-30 kHz) (Figures 24-25).

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: Typical Behavior of the Frequency-Amplitude Spectrum during Well Logging Using the Method of Spectral Noise Logging

formatted-caption.caption-text: Typical Behavior of the Frequency-Amplitude Spectrum during Well Logging Using the Method of Spectral Noise Logging

linkTarget.anchoringText: This method in combination with highly precise temperature logging enables detailing inflow intervals with the best vertical resolution (to dozens of centimeters) and determination of the inflow nature. This method is based on noise sensing in an operating well, and the frequency-amplitude characteristic of noise could indicate the environment of fluid filtration. Applying various mathematical filters to the noise spectrum in the well, the flow intervals can be directly divided by the reservoir matrix (0.3-1 kHz) and by fractures (15-30 kHz) (Figures 24-25).

image-wrap.label: Figure 25
image-wrap.caption: Composite Log Based on Well Logging Results Using High-Frequency Temperature Logging and Spectral Noise Logging of Well *3-3G at NGKM-1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Composite Log Based on Well Logging Results Using High-Frequency Temperature Logging and Spectral Noise Logging of Well *3-3G at NGKM-1

linkTarget.anchoringText: According to the analysis data, previously determined tectonic dislocations and inflow intervals determined in the course of well logging partially coincide (Figures 26-28).

linkTarget.anchoringText: According to the analysis data, previously determined tectonic dislocations and inflow intervals determined in the course of well logging partially coincide (Figures 26-28).

Gas-saturated intervals are highlighted in yellow, oilsaturated intervals - in red, water-saturated intervals - in blue. Dashed line – the fault localized by seismic attributes. Green squares – inflow intervals determined by well logging. The lower interval is determined by indirect indicators

Gas-saturated intervals are highlighted in yellow, oilsaturated intervals - in red, water-saturated intervals - in blue. Dashed line – the fault localized by seismic attributes. Green squares – inflow intervals determined by well logging. The lower interval is determined by indirect indicators

linkTarget.anchoringText: According to the analysis data, previously determined tectonic dislocations and inflow intervals determined in the course of well logging partially coincide (Figures 26-28).

image-wrap.label: Figure 28
image-wrap.caption: Composite Log Based on Results of Well Logging at Well **15G. Intervals of intensive inflow of gas-oil mixture are put in green squares. The lower interval has no express temperature anomaly, but can be determined by indirect indicators, using the grain-size analysis methods

formatted-caption.caption-text: Composite Log Based on Results of Well Logging at Well **15G. Intervals of intensive inflow of gas-oil mixture are put in green squares. The lower interval has no express temperature anomaly, but can be determined by indirect indicators, using the grain-size analysis methods

linkTarget.anchoringText: Nevertheless, despite impossibility of thorough study of nature of fractured inflow intervals, the author managed to update the well stream model for wells studied using the proposed set of studies. The algorithm of surveys is set forth in Fig. 29.

image-wrap.label: Figure 29
image-wrap.caption: Algorithm of Updating the Well Stream Model for a Horizontal Well with an Open Hole, Based on the Results of Integration of Various-Scale Studies

formatted-caption.caption-text: Algorithm of Updating the Well Stream Model for a Horizontal Well with an Open Hole, Based on the Results of Integration of Various-Scale Studies
